question.content:
At a certain time, the velocity $\bold v$ of a charged particle in a magnetic field $\bold B$ is as shown below.

[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following best represents the direction of "$-(\bold B \times \bold v)$"?**$\\$
_Note: $\bigotimes$ indicates the direction into the plane of screen._

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
##Strategy

- We can first find the cross product using the [[☃ explanation 1]]. Here, the first and second vectors are:

$\left(\underbrace{\bold{B}}_{\text{First vector}} \times \underbrace{\bold{v}}_{\text{Second vector}}\right)$. 

- Next, we can take the negative of the vector by reversing its direction.

options.explanation: To use the right hand rule, we open up our right hand and then[[☃ explanation 1]] from the first vector to the second vector. The stretched thumb then indicates the direction of the cross product.
_To curl your fingers, just make a fist with your fingers but keep your thumb stretched._

hints.content:
##Solution

We start with the stretched right hand, with fingers pointing towards the vector $\bold B$ (inwards). Then, we curl the fingers towards the second vector $\bold v$.

[[☃ image 1]]

On doing this, the thumb points in the direction of $(\bold B\times \bold v)$.

Next, we simply reverse the direction obtained above to get the direction of "$-(\bold B \times \bold v)$".

The direction of $-(\bold B \times \bold v)$ is:


[[☃ image 1]]
